awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Fundamental materials studies on fast ion diffusion in model side-chain ionomers.
awd_abstract_narration:
PART 1:   NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The objectives of this CAREER project are to design, prepare, and characterize model polymers to elucidate fundamental understanding of the parameters governing motion of ions in specialized plastics materials.  At the same time, it will integrate educational and outreach programs to excite and encourage future STEM (i.e., science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) researchers, recruit female undergraduate students to STEM careers, and support and retain female STEM researchers at the graduate and postdoctoral levels.  The PI aims to synthesize novel polymers that will allow for specific hypotheses regarding ion transport to be probed by in-depth material characterization.  The project integrates skills and knowledge of chemistry, materials science, and chemical engineering to interrogate fundamental structure-property relationships.  The fundamental scientific knowledge generated by this work could enable advances in new materials for applications including safer high energy-density rechargeable batteries.  Additionally, the number, diversity, and training of the next generation of researchers in the chemical sciences and engineering will be addressed by the development and dissemination of a polymers module at high schools, laboratory research experiences for high school students and teachers, targeted recruitment of female undergraduate students to research opportunities, and mentoring of a graduate and postdoctoral women's group.  



PART 2:   TECHNICAL SUMMARY

In this project, a tunable model system will be leveraged to enable understanding of the fundamentals of ion diffusion in ionomer ionic aggregates, a potential mechanism for facilitating fast single-ion transport in solvent-free polymers.  This research aims to propel understanding of this ion diffusion mechanism through targeted experimental studies that span novel polymer synthesis and in-depth material characterization.  Specifically, model ionomers with tunable terminal ionic groups that self-assemble into defined phases will be synthesized and further leveraged to interrogate the parameters affecting the rate of counter-ion transport in ionic domains.  Molecular-level through mesoscale structural characterization as well as characterization of counter-ion and matrix dynamics will enable fundamental structure-property correlations to be made.    The research is integrated with an educational plan by involvement of undergraduate researchers, including female undergraduates from St. Mary's College, in the research activities and dissemination of a "Polymers in Our World" module to high schools.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Polymer electrolytes are polymer (plastic) materials that conduct ions but are insulating to electrons. The understanding of ion motion in polymer electrolytes is important for the advancement of various technologies, including solid-state batteries, fuel cells, and transistors. In this project, the research team created a new family of plastics that are side-chain ionomers, polymers with a side-chain terminated in an ionic group in every molecular unit. The lithiated form of the ionomers was studied in order to understand how the lithium ion motion is correlated with the molecular and mesoscale structure and the dynamics of the polymer.

This project resulted in several technical outcomes. Families of new side-chain ionomers were synthesized for the first time. These side-chain ionomers were found to have ion motion orders of magnitude faster than the conventional ionomer with ions immediately adjacent to the main-chain and lacking long side-chains. The side-chain ionomers with non-polar main-chains were found to self-assemble with regular segregation of the ions and non-polar segments, resulting in ordered, nanoscale ionic domains. In contrast, the side-chain ionomers with polar main-chains were disordered with interactions between the ions and the main-chains. The long-range ion motion that dictates the bulk ionic conductivity is found to be correlated with dielectric relaxation and also limited by boundaries between the ionic domains. In addition, ionic surfactants were also synthesized as small-molecule analogs to compare with the side-chain ionomers. These lithiated surfactants were demonstrated as single-component lithium-conducting electrolytes, and some compositions were classified as ionic liquid crystals. The ion motion in both the side-chain ionomers and ionic surfactants was generally found to be faster for bound anion types with more delocalized electronic charge.

Over the course of the project, five graduate students, and twelve undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral scholar were trained in research methods. Of those, two graduate students and eight undergraduate students are from underrepresented groups in the STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) workforce. A 'Polymers in Our World' outreach module was developed for use in high school chemistry classrooms, and activities were developed for use in public settings for education of children and their parents about polymers. The PI served continuously as a faculty mentor for her engineering department's Graduate and Postdoctoral Women's group that seeks to support and retain female researchers at the graduate and postdoctoral levels.


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Jennifer L Schaefer

Images (1 of )
  • Schematics of a traditional lithium ionomer with disordered ion and a side-chain ionomer. The side-chain ionomer has ionic conductivity that is about 5 orders of magnitude faster than that of traditional ionomer LiPSTFSI at 140 degrees Celsius.
    Jennifer L. Schaefer
    Copyrighted
    Jennifer L Schaefer
    Side-chain ionomer versus conventional ionomer
  • Ionic side-chain length of polymers with rigid main-chain influences ion conducting domain morphology. Polymers with short side-chains were found to self-assemble with a mixture of layered and hexagonal ionic domains. Polymers with longer side-chains were found to self-assemble with ionic layers.
    Jennifer L. Schaefer
    Copyrighted
    Jennifer L Schaefer
    Influence of side-chain length
  • Schematic of side-chain polymer with self-assembled, nanoscale ionic aggregates. Ions are located on the termini of the side-chains. Ionic aggregates are discontinuous at the grain boundary. Data indicates that ion motion across the grain boundary limits bulk ionic conductivity.
    Jennifer L. Schaefer
    Copyrighted
    Jennifer L Schaefer
    Side-chain polymer with ion aggregates
